dtliExcerpt: The effervescent new musical comedy “Two Strangers (Carry a Cake Across New York),” which opened on Thursday at the Longacre Theater, is the most charmingly simple show on Broadway right now — a stellar debut for its authors, Jim Barne and Kit Buchan, and the actor Sam Tutty, who plays the irrepressible Dougal. Transferred from London’s West End by way of Cambridge, Mass., this twinkly two-hander delivers lavishly on the promise of a rom-com: laughter, escape and fantasy.
showScoreExcerpt: Critic’s Pick: "The effervescent new musical comedy...is the most charmingly simple show on Broadway right now — a stellar debut for its authors... and the actor Sam Tutty."

The use of 'Critic’s Pick' further supports the rave classification. | Gemini: The review uses strong positive language like "effervescent", "charming", "stellar", and "lavishly delivers" indicating a strong recommendation. The critic clearly enjoyed the show and its performances.

bwwExcerpt: Laura Collins-Hughes, The New York Times: As gleefully as the musical follows the formula of the rom-com genre, it also has a welcome comfort with ambiguity and, stashed up its sleeve, some psychological bombs. The action floats along so comfortably, both in and out of song, that it seems odd to interrupt that momentum with an intermission. But the second act brings a stark shift in tone, getting darker for a while before rebounding with great silliness and gratifying sympathy.
